Award.AwardTitle: Conference on the work of W. Hugh Woodin
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for participants to Conference on the work of W. Hugh Woodin,to be held at Harvard University during March 27-29, 2015. Professor Woodin has been one of the top figures in mathematical logic since the early 1980's, and he has made important contributions to other areas, both in mathematics and philosophy. In addition to his many results, Woodin has introduced a number of important technical methods, and he has been the primary developer of some of the deepest areas of foundational research. The meeting will attract a diverse audience, and it will promote awareness and understanding of Woodin's work and its importance. For younger researchers, it will be an excellent opportunity to interact with some of the best-known figures in mathematical logic. Funds are requested to cover the travel expenses of the speakers and student participants.

The conference will focus on areas to which Woodin has made major contributions include applications of set theory to analysis, forcing and large cardinals (especially work on the continuum function), the relationship between large cardinals and the Axiom of Determinacy, forcing over models of determinacy, using inner models to prove lower bounds in consistency strength for natural combinatorial statements via his core model induction technique, building inner models for the largest large cardinals, the structure of the Turing degrees, and the philosophy of set theory. Much of this work is unpublished, technically deep and understood in detail by only small groups of experts. The speakers for the meeting have been chosen to cover as much of this ground as possible. More details on the conference can be found at the web site http://logic.harvard.edu/woodin_meeting.html.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported a conference held in honor of Professor W. Hugh Woodin, held at Harvard University on March 27-29, 2015. Woodin has been one of the top two figures in set theory since the early 1980's, and has done important work in several related areas, including the philosophy of mathematics. His work is known for its technical depth and innovation, and he has produced many fundamental results. However, many of his techniques have still not been absorbed by the larger community. This conference was designed to promote understanding of his work.

The conference program consisted of nine one-hour lectures given over a three day period, allowing sufficient time for discussion and individual interaction. The invited speakers included most of Woodin's closest collaborators, along with some of the top experts on his work. Most of the talks were on topics in set theory related to Woodin's  research. One, covering material related to Woodin's earliest work, was on set-theoretic independence in functional analysis; another was on Woodin's work in recursion theory. Approximately 60 researchers attended the meeting, including his advisor, Robert Solovay, and several of his former graduate students. A significant portion of those attending were current graduate students. For these younger researchers, it was a unique opportunity to interact with prominent figures in mathematical logic.

A volume of papers related to the conference has been published by the American Mathematical Society. The authors of these papers included conference speakers, attendees of the conference, Woodin's former graduate students and other researchers in areas related to Woodin's work.
